Trial_Design.evidence: residents were randomized 1:1 using permuted-block design stratified by site, training level, and gender

Participants.evidence: 96 individuals with academic career interests met eligibility criteria; 86 residents completed phase 1

Intervention.evidence: Residents read abstracts that either reported that women had worse laparoscopic skill performance than men (trigger of stereotype threat [A]) or had no difference in performance (protection against stereotype threat [B])

Objective.evidence: To evaluate the association between pro-male gender bias and career engagement and the effect of stereotype threat on skill performance among trainees in academic surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Association between perception of pro-male gender bias and career engagement survey scores (phase 1) and stereotype threat intervention and FLS scores (phase 2) were the outcomes.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: residents were randomized 1:1 using permuted-block design stratified by site, training level, and gender

Number_Randomised.evidence: Eighty-five residents were randomized in phase 2, and 4 residents in each arm were lost to follow-up.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Seventy-seven residents (38 women [49.4%]) completed both phases of the study.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The association between pro-male gender bias and career engagement differed by gender (interaction coefficient, −1.19; 95% CI, −1.90 to −0.49; P = .02)
